p: All environmental variables included in the RDA accounted for 35.6% of the total variation. The results of stepwise forward selection of variables indicated that five variables: anthropogenic disturbances (Anthrop), carbonates (CaCO 3), loose sand presence (LoSa), potassium (K), and soil moisture content (Moist) were statistically significant and varied between the studied populations of I. capensis ( Fig. 4). Along the gradient represented by Axis I, the highest correlation between the sample position and environmental variables (the so-called interset correlation) was typical of anthropogenic disturbances and CaCO 3, followed by the degree of shading and soil Ca, while the C/N ratio was most closely correlated with Axis II, followed by soil content of P, Na, K, and organic soil.
